awd_titl_txt: Dynamical Systems and Singular Perturbation Theory for Multiscale Reaction-Diffusion Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project encompasses a series of critical mathematical and scientific questions for multiscale problems arising in the fields of pattern formation, chemistry and combustion, neuroscience, electrical engineering, and multi-particle systems. The first project is on pattern formation and analyzes the dynamics and stability of fronts, pulses, and spots in paradigm reaction-diffusion systems. The second project studies model reduction methods used in complex multiscale chemical reactions, biochemical networks, and combustion by incorporating also the effects of diffusion. The third project involves a completely new class of solutions, known as torus canards, found in models from neuroscience. These solutions help understand the transitions between periodic spiking and bursting. The fourth project will focus on ways to model and analyze the impacts of cut-offs on the dynamics of fronts. The project involves graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in the research, as well as collaborations with scientists at national laboratories. 

This research project addresses a series of questions concerning multiscale problems in pattern formation, chemistry and combustion, neuroscience, electrical engineering, and multi-particle systems. In the pattern formation project, paradigm reaction-diffusion systems will be studied. The goals are to develop new analytical techniques and mathematical theory for determining the boundaries of the stable pattern-forming regimes, analyzing the stability of semi-strong pulse interactions, modeling the scattering of pulses in 1-D systems and spots in 2-D systems, extending renormalization group methods for stability of modulating pulses, and predicting the dynamic bifurcations of pulses and fronts. The second project centers on accurate model reduction methods for large-scale combustion, chemical, and biochemical systems exhibiting multiple time scales. The goals are to analyze, develop, and improve cutting-edge model reduction methods for finding the low-dimensional manifolds that govern the effective system dynamics in the presence of diffusion. In the third project, the new phenomena of torus canards and canards in partial differential equations will be investigated. A theory of generic torus canards will be developed for fast-slow systems with multi-dimensional fast and slow variables. Known to exist in many neuroscience models, such as the Hindmarsh-Rose equations, the Morris-Lecar-Terman model, the Wilson-Cowan-Izhikevich system, and the forced van der Pol equation, torus canards are critical in the transition regimes between tonic spiking and bursting. A detailed study will also be carried out of the new bursting rhythms known as amplitude-modulated bursting rhythms. The fourth project will study the impacts of cut-offs on the reaction terms, introduced to accurately model regions of low particle densities, on the speeds, shapes, and stability of propagating fronts. A series of important problems related to fourth-order models, two-dimensional space dynamics, front initiation, and front pre-cursors will be studied.

por.por_cntn:
In physics, neuroscience, chemistry, biology, and engineering, the fundamental dynamics of many phenomena occur on multiple time-scales and over multiple length-scales. For example, rhythms in nerve cells range from low-frequency (0.02 Hz) to high frequency (100 Hz or more). Also, in chemistry and combustion, reaction rates vary over many orders of magnitude (nanoseconds to tens of seconds), as do diffusion length scales.

In this project, new mathematical theory was developed to study the dynamics of multi-scale systems in physics, neuroscience, chemistry, and engineering problems. Moreover, as the mathematical theory was developed, a number of new phenomena were discovered in these fields, and new mathematical methods were established in dynamical systems, singular perturbations, stability theory in partial differential equations, asymptotic analysis, and pattern formation, thereby also significantly advancing these useful fields of mathematics.

During the project, the brand new phenomenon of delayed Hopf bifurcations was discovered in spatially-extended systems. Delayed Hopf bifurcation was studied in the Complex Ginzburg-Landau equation in pattern formation, a spatially-extended pituitary-lactotroph model in neuroscience, the FitzHugh-Nagumo equation, the Brusselator model in chemistry, and other multi-scale systems. Project research showed that solutions of these systems actually remain near key states, even for long times after the states have become unstable due to slow passage through Hopf bifurcations. This delay is critical for postponing the destabilization of desirable states and suppressing the onset of oscilllations. Analytical formulas were derived for the space-time buffer curves which control the space-time dependencies of the delayed, post-Hopf onset of the oscillations.

A new type of attractor, called Multi-Mode Attractors, was discovered in reaction-diffusion systems during the project. These attractors exhibit different modes of temporal oscillation (spiking, alternating small- and large-amplitude oscillations, and bursting) in different regions of the domains. They were found in models of spatially-extended systems of pituitary-lactotroph cells and of cardiac myocytes, during Early After Depolarization. Moreover, new spatio-temporal canards were discovered in the transition intervals between adjacent regions.

Mixed-Amplitude Chimeras were discovered during the project. In chimera states, systems of coupled oscillators exhibit regions of coherent (synchronous) oscillations co-existing with regions of decoherent (asynchronous) oscillations. For the new Mixed-Amplitude Chimeras, the coherent oscillators exhibit large-amplitude, low-frequency oscillations, while the decoherent oscillators exhibit small-amplitude, high-frequency oscillations. These substantial differences in the structures, amplitudes, and frequencies are important for oscillators in the different regions to have different functional roles.

Analysis was performed of the dynamics and stability of pulses in multi-scale reaction-diffusion systems. Also, the effects of cutoffs on fronts and front propagation speeds were studied.

During the project, mathematical analysis was performed to determine the accuracy and efficiency of several state-of-the-art model reduction and dimension-reduction methods, which are widely used in chemistry, combustion science, biochemistry, and engineering. These methods are typically designed to find low-dimensional invariant manifolds in state space, thereby decomposing large, intractable multi-scale systems into tractable, low-dimensional models. Substantial design and implementation improvements were also made. Further, a new class of nonlinear partial differential equations was discovered that have exact, closed-form, low-dimensional invariant manifolds, making these new PDEs valuable to benchmark reduction methods.

The project research developed new mathematical theory for torus canards, which occur ubiquitously in neuroscience.Their primary geometric and genericity properties were determined, for how they mediate the transitions between tonic spiking and many different types of bursting, as were mechanisms responsible for their creation, and formulas for their dependence on system parameters. The new phenomenon of Amplitude Modulated Bursting (AMB) was discovered while studying torus canards. AMB is a novel class of rhythms in which burst events are modulated in amplitude, which is important for extending burst duration and functional roles. Mathematically, it was shown that AMB is created by a new class of singularities in differential equations, called folded toral singularities, for which the first theory was developed by Vo. Finally, it was shown that torus canards arise in the prototypical forced van der Pol model in electrical engineering, thereby expanding the range of applications beyond neuroscience.

With support from this project, a total of twenty original research articles were written by the PI, along with PhD students, postdocs, and collaborators, to disseminate the results. These were published in top applied mathematics, physics, and scientific journals, or are currently under review. Also, the PI gave 19 invited talks at major national and international conferences, universities, and institutes.

The broader impacts of this project included the training of five PhD students in mathematics and three postdoctoral fellows, half men and half women. The postdocs became professorial faculty members at research universities after their training. Two of the PhD students are now postdoctoral fellows in mathematics, another is employed as a Research Scientist at a major data science company, and the other two are current students. As part of their training, the PhD students and postdocs disseminated their research by presenting at major research conferences.

  • Delayed Hopf Bifurcation in the Complex Ginzburg-Landau equation of pattern formation. The solution stays near the unstable state (green) well past the Hopf bifurcation (mu=0). The delayed onset of oscillations occurs in a spatially-dependent manner, near the space-time buffer curve (past mu=0.5).
    Goh, Kaper, Vo, IMA JAM, 2022
    Copyrighted
    Tasso J Kaper
    Delayed Hopf Bifurcation
  • A Multi-Mode Attractor consisting of three different modes of oscillation across an array of pituitary cells controlling lactotroph release. Near cells exhibit 1^1 plateau bursting, far cells undergo spiking, and cells in the middle alternately burst and spike, as also seen in the time series.
    Vo, Bertram. Kaper, Physica D, 2020
    Copyrighted
    Tasso J Kaper
    A representative three-mode MMA
  • Amplitude-modulated bursting rhythms in the Politi-Hofer model of intracellular calcium dynamics. Transitions through the rotational sectors of the folded toral singularities (left) create AMBs with different numbers of oscillations in the burst envelopes (right). Boundaries are torus canards.
    Kaper, Kramer, Vo, PRL 2016
    Copyrighted
    Tasso J Kaper
    Amplitude-Modulated Bursting
